awd_titl_txt: CAS: ENFORCING EXCITED STATE REACTIVITY BY ALTERING CHROMOPHORE CHARACTERISTICS
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism-B program in the Division of Chemistry supports the fundamental research of Professor Jayaraman Sivaguru and his students at Bowling Green State University (BGSU) in Ohio. The Sivaguru group harnesses the power of light to create sustainable strategies for carrying out new chemical transformations. They develop new models to understand the fundamental aspects and to control light–induced reactivity. The overarching goal is to build complex molecular structures in an energy efficient and sustainable fashion.  This project integrates the research and academic goals of teaching and learning to help students gain experimental and intellectual competence. The broader impacts of the program include research by high school students in northwest Ohio through an outreach program called PICNICS (Parents Involvement with Children, Nurturing Intellectual Curiosity in Science). This program provides summer internships for local high school juniors and seniors. This enables the students to learn first-hand about recent advancements in science, and to gain experience working in a cutting-edge research environment in BGSU’s Center for Photochemical Sciences.

The research plan develops strategies for directing excited state reactivity, uncovering new photochemical reactivity, and achieving reaction selectivity by altering the normal characteristics of chromophores.  The electronic characteristics of reactive chromophores are modified either by internal substitution or through external additives such as Lewis acids.  This work is designed to reveal new photochemical pathways and reactivity that are not observed in conventional systems. The research seeks to understand the delicate balance between reactivity, selectivity, dynamics, and lifetimes of molecular excited state and short-lived intermediates. One goal is to create new paradigms related to photochemical and photophysical events using altered chromophore characteristics. The outcome of the proposed investigations provides a platform to build complex molecules with pre-defined configurations, in an energy efficient and sustainable fashion. The results have a significant impact on basic concepts related to the photosciences and broadly influence the fields of synthesis, materials science, organic optoelectronics, catalysis and environmental science. This research provides opportunities for student training and integration of research in public outreach programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our investigation on “Enforcing Excited State Reactivity by Altering Chromophore Characteristics” has uncovered novel excited state reactivities that can be controlled leading to photochemical pathways that are both efficient and broad in scope. The developed strategies are based on internal and/or external activation of substrates that alter the electronic characteristics enhancing photoreactivity in both unimolecular and bimolecular photoreactions. The internal activation approach relied on altering the electronic characteristics of well-known chromophores by strategic substitutions. This led to an unprecedented and previously unknown photochemical reactivity of 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds with amino-alkenes leading to dihydropyrans. This novel photochemical reactivity changed the established paradigm related to the De Mayo reaction between 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and alkenes. We were also able to uncover a new type [2+4]-photocycloaddition instead of the traditional [2+2]-photocycloaddition providing an alternative pathway to access stereoisomeric products that are complementary to what was observed in thermal reactions. Our second approach (external activation approach) utilized cations/Lewis acids to manipulate photoreactions leading to new reactivity and to enhance selectivity. Our strategy depended on harnessing the short lifetimes of reactive excited state(s) and/or intermediates and exploiting the delicate balance of reactivity, selectivity, dynamics and lifetimes that are difficult to comprehend in excited state processes. Our research findings were disseminated in top-tier peer-reviewed chemistry journals. The findings from the projects were also disseminated in various national and international conferences and were well received by the scientific community as evidenced by the awards and recognitions given to students who carried out the proposed research and the PI who directed the research program.

The completed research projects are highly interdisciplinary in nature that helped students gain experimental competence in the fields’ of organic photochemistry, photophysics, photocatalysis and separation techniques. Coupled with the PI’s integrated approach to intellectual, scientific and educational activities, students were able to achieve their academic goals related to research training, teaching, and learning. These aspects helped students gain experimental and intellectual competence that was reflected in their career path after successful completion of their PhD. The program successfully recruited and supervised students from underrepresented groups all of whom completed their doctoral investigations and received their degree during the award period. Students who successfully completed their doctoral work took up positions as post-doctoral fellows in top institutions in the US as well as in national labs. Students trained in the PIs program also took positions as research scientists in industry. The PI also trained undergraduate students that included students from underrepresented groups. The undergraduate students are currently pursing doctoral studies in chemistry in top institutions. Thus, the PI’s research program was able to train next generation of researchers.

 The research program also trained high school students. The funding for the research program enabled the PI to develop and sustain a unique outreach program for high school students called PICNICS “Parents Involvement with Children, Nurturing Intellectual Curiosity in Sciences”. Thirty-one high school students participated in the program during the award period from eight participating schools in northwest Ohio region. A total of 96 students have participated in the PICNICS summer program since its inception in 2007. This program continues to train and provide research opportunities to high school students. This has enabled talented high school students to gain a wide range of experience and expertise in interdisciplinary and collaborative research and create an infrastructure for the integration of research and education. This initiative would not have been feasible without the generous funding from NSF.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2024
Modified by: Jayaraman Sivaguru
